item.title: 6 Takeaways From the First Batch of the Epstein Files
item.description: Many of the Justice Department documents were heavily redacted, and President Trump’s name was rarely mentioned. The White House also sought to make political hay of the release of photos of Bill Clinton.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

item.title: Epstein Files Timeline: How the Trump Administration Released Records
item.description: A year of political pressure and partial disclosures preceded the release of long-sought records on Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has faced persistent scrutiny over his shifting stance on the release of Justice Department files related to Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Epstein Victims Upset About Lack of Transparency in Newly Released Files
item.description: Several victims said they were frustrated by the heavy redactions of photos and documents that the Justice Department released on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein and Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Survivors spoke during a news conference on the Epstein Files Transparency Act ahead of the House vote to release the files in November.

item.title: Epstein Files Include 1996 Child Porn Complaint That F.B.I. Ignored
item.description: Newly released files show how Maria Farmer, who worked for Mr. Epstein in the 1990s, had urged the F.B.I. to investigate him. The case went nowhere for years.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker and Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Andrea Morales for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Farmer in 2019.

item.title: U.S. Strikes Islamic State Targets in Syria
item.description: American forces struck dozens of suspected ISIS sites, making good on President Trump’s vow to avenge two American soldiers and a civilian U.S. interpreter killed by the group last week.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The dignified transfer of the American soldiers killed in Syria. The assault last weekend was a stark reminder of the danger in the region and the quandary of whether to keep American forces there at all.

item.title: Trump Picks New Leader for Southern Command as Venezuela Pressure Grows
item.description: Lt. Gen. Francis L. Donovan, a Marine general with expansive experience in special operations and the Middle East, would take over after the abrupt departure of the previous commander.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: U.S. Marine Corps
item.media:description: If confirmed by the Senate, Lt. Gen. Francis L. Donovan would take over as boat strikes in the Caribbean and Pacific have come under sharp criticism from lawmakers from both parties.

item.title: Elise Stefanik Drops Out of N.Y. Governor’s Race and Will Leave Congress
item.description: Ms. Stefanik, a Republican congresswoman and staunch ally of President Trump, abruptly ended her bid to unseat Gov. Kathy Hochul and said she would not seek another House term.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Elise Stefanik is one of President Trump’s most steadfast supporters, but he had shied away from endorsing her in the New York governor’s race.

item.title: Elise Stefanik Tried Everything to Please Trump. He Still Jilted Her.
item.description: The G.O.P. congresswoman who ran as a moderate but became an “ultra MAGA” Trump acolyte ultimately found herself undermined by the president and politically adrift.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elise Stefanik’s tumble from grace crystallized the limits of MAGA loyalty and the risks of building a political identity around President Trump.

item.title: Suspected Killer of M.I.T. Professor Studied With Victim, Graduating Top of Their Class
item.description: The parents of the suspect in the Brown and M.I.T. killings had not seen or heard from him since he left Portugal to enroll at a graduate program at Brown more than two decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Azam Ahmed, Dana Goldstein and Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Bildagentur/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Claudio Neves Valente and Nuno Loureiro, the M.I.T. professor he is accused of killing, were classmates at the University of Lisbon’s Instituto Superior Técnico from 1995 to 2000.

item.title: Suspect in Brown and M.I.T. Killings Died 2 Days Before He Was Found, Autopsy Shows
item.description: The examination confirmed that the suspect had died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound. His body was found late Thursday in a storage unit in New Hampshire.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: The suspect’s body was found in a storage facility in Salem, N.H., late Thursday.

item.title: How a Reddit Post Helped the Police Identify a Suspect in the Brown University Shooting
item.description: A Reddit user provided information that helped identify Claudio Manuel Neves Valente as the suspect not only in the campus shooting but also in the murder of an M.I.T. professor.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vehicle was loaded onto a tow truck outside the storage facility in Salem, N.H., where the Brown University shooting suspect’s body was found on Thursday.

item.title: 52 Places to Go, So Little Time: Where We Went in 2025
item.description: Our writers and photographers were on the ground to find out what makes the destinations on our annual list rise above the rest.
item.dc:creator: Tacey Rychter
item.media:credit: Piotr Krzeslak/Shutterstock
item.media:description: The Lofoten archipelago is a dreamy base for adventure, with backcountry ski slopes, hiking trails, deep fjords to sail and a front-row view of the northern lights.

item.title: R.F.K. Jr. Likely to Swap U.S. Childhood Vaccine Schedule for Denmark’s
item.description: The shift would mean fewer shots recommended for children. But a Danish health official found the idea baffling, saying the United States was getting “crazier and crazier in public health.”
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Fabian Sommer/picture alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A pediatrician administering a combination six-way vaccination against diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, poliomyelitis, Haemophilus influenzae type b and hepatitis B, in Berlin.

item.title: How the T.S.A. Is Helping ICE
item.description: In a previously undisclosed partnership, the Transportation Security Administration and Immigration and Customs Enforcement are sharing data to identify passengers on upcoming flights whom ICE can arrest. Our reporter Hamed Aleaziz, who learned of this partnership, describes what to know about it and the ICE arrests that have followed.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz, Melanie Bencosme, June Kim, Pierre Kattar and Whitney Shefte

item.title: Kennedy Center, Memorial to JFK, Is Trump’s Now, Too
item.description: The Kennedy Center installed President Trump’s name on the facade of the arts center, which had been designated as a living memorial to President John F. Kennedy.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crew members unveiling the new name of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Friday morning.

item.title: Immigration Officials Deport Queens 6-Year-Old and Father Who Fled China
item.description: Hundreds of people had rallied for the family in New York City after they were separated by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents in November.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ley and Hamed Aleaziz

item.title: Rubio Meets (and Meets, and Meets … ) the Press
item.description: The secretary of state held a marathon news conference, offering little news but more respect for reporters than most others in the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Kevin Mohatt/Reuters
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio fielded questions from reporters for more than two hours on Friday.

item.title: Sudanese Refugees Describe Their Escape From Darfur
item.description: No one knows the true toll of the massacre, and the city remains isolated. Now, refugee camps in Chad are flooded with newly displaced Sudanese.
item.dc:creator: Ivor Prickett
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Vivek Ramaswamy Challenges Conservatives on Surging Anti-Indian Hate
item.description: The leading Republican candidate for Ohio governor is calling out his party for rising intolerance, including against Indian American immigrants and their children, like him.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry/Associated Press

item.title: ‘Where’s the Humanity?’ Bondi Attack Leaves Suspects’ Neighborhood Stunned
item.description: The alleged gunmen in the shooting, Sajid Akram, 50 and his son, Naveed Akram, 24, were from Bonnyrigg, a diverse, multilingual suburb miles from Sydney’s Bondi Beach.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka, Max Kim and Matthew Abbott
item.media:description: A pedestrian overpass spanning a main road on Friday in Bonnyrigg, a multicultural suburb of Sydney.

item.title: Bumpy Rollout for New Gates Meant to Stop Subway Fare Evasion
item.description: At a demonstration of devices designed to replace turnstiles, one rider got hit in the neck, and another sneaked through without paying.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen
item.media:credit: Marco Postigo Storel for The New York Times
item.media:description: In addition to combating fare evasion, the new type of gates are expected to make coming and going easier for riders with disabilities, as well as those with strollers or suitcases.

item.title: Metro-North and LIRR Commuters to Be Fined for ‘Repeatedly’ Activating Tickets on Train
item.description: Passengers on Metro-North and Long Island Rail Road trains could face $8 fines if they keep waiting until after the train leaves to activate their mobile tickets.
item.dc:creator: Camille Baker
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie/The New York Times
item.media:description: There was no set number of late activations or late ticket purchases that would trigger the charge, a spokeswoman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said.

item.title: Hochul Expected to Veto Bill Requiring 2-Person Crews on Subway Trains
item.description: The bill, which would ensure that every train has a conductor and a driver, as most now do, was supported by the transit workers’ union and opposed by many transit advocates.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: A conductor on an A train in Manhattan in March, 2024.

item.title: Hochul Reaches Deal on A.I. Regulation in New York
item.description: The bill, which lawmakers passed in June, will be modified to more closely match a similar law in California, at Big Tech’s urging.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.media:credit: Kent J. Edwards for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul at Grand Central Terminal in December.

item.title: Mamdani Revamps Hiring After Old Antisemitic Remarks Prompt Aide to Quit
item.description: Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani said he did not know about the antisemitic posts and would not have hired the woman who made them if he had.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Heather Khalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Catherine Almonte Da Costa, left, resigned a day after Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani appointed her to oversee administration hiring.

item.title: Lou Cannon Dies at 92; Journalist Chronicled Reagan as an Author
item.description: He was a foremost authority on the president, tracing his career in unvarnished accounts from his time as California governor through his years in the White House.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden

item.title: Mitt Romney: Tax the Rich, Like Me
item.description: There’s no getting around this if we want to avoid the deficit cliff ahead.
item.dc:creator: Mitt Romney
item.media:credit: Ben Hickey

item.title: Times Readers Open Up About the Real Cost of Motherhood
item.description: What’s the real cost of motherhood? Here’s what our readers said.
item.dc:creator: Emily Holzknecht, Adam Westbrook and Jessica Grose

item.title: Toss a Coin in the Trevi Fountain? That’ll Be 2 Euros, Wish Not Included
item.description: Starting on Feb. 1, Rome will charge tourists a fee to go down into the basin of the famed 18th-century fountain. Not every one is happy (except Romans, who won’t have to pay).
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Andrew Medichini/Associated Press
item.media:description: Visitors admiring the Trevi Fountain in Rome, on Friday. The small square around it is often densely packed.

item.title: High Winds in Denver Prompt Warnings About Dangerous Fire Risk
item.description: Emergency authorities across the region urged people to stay home, and a utility company cut off power to 100,000 of its customers near Denver.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy and Amy Graff

item.title: Two NJ Transit Trains Collide, Injuring More Than a Dozen People
item.description: The incident Friday evening shut down the Montclair-Boonton Line in Montclair, N.J.
item.dc:creator: Camille Baker

item.title: Mangione’s Lawyers Take Issue With Bondi’s Ties to UnitedHealthcare
item.description: Lawyers for Luigi Mangione, who is accused of killing UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive, say Attorney General Pam Bondi should have recused herself from the case.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Attorney General Pam Bondi recently worked for a lobbying firm that lists UnitedHealthcare’s parent company among its clients.
